intro: Papaver tauricola var. microcarpum, commonly known as the Crimean poppy, is a variant of the Crimean poppy native to the steppes of southern Russia and Ukraine. It is a herbaceous perennial that produces striking red to orange flowers with a distinctive black center. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and has lance-shaped leaves with a rough, hairy texture. Its flowers bloom in late spring to early summer, and the plant produces small, capsule-like fruits containing numerous seeds. It is often cultivated for its ornamental value and is adapted to dry, well-drained soils.
